segments.text: Will Davis, for example, strong advocate of community in Austin.
Will's going to run again.
He'll probably get elected.
If we get enough people like Will Davis on there, and one thing I think is probably,

going to help us is this whole area of at-risk use dropout prevention the latchkey child the whole thing of drug and sex education the the terminal of alternative schools fits in very nicely for community ed to be a delivery system for part or all of some of these new mandated required programs i think if we can

if we can convince these legislators that community education is the logical delivery system of a lot of these support programs that are now mandated by law for local school districts to implement, I think that's going to be our key to the next big wave of new projects in community education.
It's going to be a heavy

involvement and integration of the K-12 program and some of those sustaining programs that deal with the real critical issues of dropout prevention, the latch key thing, the tutorials, the drug abuse, the teenage pregnancies.
I think community education is just a natural extension of the school day that can provide the programs and services needed to if not prevent

at least turn around or make more people aware of the alternatives that hopefully will slow and eventually stop the tremendous numbers that we're losing to dropouts, to the pregnancy things, to people addicted to drugs and the whole cycle.
The Secretary of State in a meeting yesterday mentioned the fact that we're not getting enough of the federal funds that are out there, that Texas is really way down.
on the scale of federal funds.
Are there not a lot of federal funds available for these kinds of things that community ed, for example, could?
I know they're already getting some.
I've heard of some recently, like these programs for single parent and so forth.
Are they encouraged or directors encouraged to actively pursue those?
That's probably going to be an alternative source of funding that once the need is really adequately addressed by local school districts and the state puts

primary responsibility of the local district to pick up and fund these and at the same time these local school districts know the availability of selected federal funds to offset some of the cost to the local school district I think we're going to see a much higher level of activity by local school districts writing for and receiving these federal grants and in part of the administrative costs to administer these programs will also serve a dual purpose of writing
of covering some of the administrative costs of the community education programs.
So I think that is something positive.
And I think in the future those funds are only going to increase with the federal government.
I think we'll see a new wave of support for education with the new presidential
platform and policies of the next administration for the next four to eight years.
I think education is going to be on the forefront.
I think a result of that is going to be a lot more federal dollars again flowing to local states and the local school districts.
Unlike the Reagan years when he tried to turn it over to the local states, most states
And I think the new wave of federal government is going to be to, in selected areas, increase the funding and assist local states and school districts to provide services to kids.
Okay.
All right.
Anything in closing that you would like to wrap up with?
You've given me a lot of very, very good insights, and I appreciate it.
Any anecdote or anything that you would like to wrap this?
No, I just think probably the legislature...

for the morale of the university faculties by the generous raises that were afforded faculties at state universities and colleges that just kind of made a, recommitted the legislature, recommitted itself to quality education and the importance of higher education.
And it was demonstrated not only verbally but financially to university professors to the extent of 10, 11% increase this year with the promise of another 10, 11% of growth next year.
And when faculty members feel that they're not only appreciated but are financially rewarded for their services, it just tends to bring the best out of the faculty.
And they tend to work more tireless toward the end of providing quality education.
And I think that probably single act over the last 12 months will carry us well into the 1990s as far as showing intent.

to support a high quality education by maintaining the highest quality faculty that money can buy and then rewarding that faculty once they have demonstrated quality service by giving them adequate financial rewards so they don't have to seek those financial rewards in the private sector.
Very good.
Dr. Stark, I thank you very, very much and I hope you let me come back and ask you questions as this develops and I try to analyze all of the data.
Thank you and thank you for being here.
